question:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, and difficulty walking up stairs. He had been well until 1 week ago, when he developed rhinorrhea, cough, and a sore throat. These symptoms resolved spontaneously 2 days ago. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. On arrival, he is pale and in moderate respiratory distress. Pulse is 120/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. On pulmonary examination, crackles are heard throughout the lung fields. On cardiac examination, a gallop is heard. S1 is soft. A grade 2/6, high-pitched holosystolic murmur is heard best at the apex. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Glomerulonephritis
(B) Myocarditis
(C) Pneumonia
(D) Rheumatic fever
(E) Systemic lupus erythematosus
question_context: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, and difficulty walking up stairs. He had been well until 1 week ago, when he developed rhinorrhea, cough, and a sore throat. These symptoms resolved spontaneously 2 days ago. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. On arrival, he is pale and in moderate respiratory distress. Pulse is 120/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. On pulmonary examination, crackles are heard throughout the lung fields. On cardiac examination, a gallop is heard. S1 is soft. A grade 2/6, high-pitched holosystolic murmur is heard best at the apex. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options:
(A) Glomerulonephritis
(B) Myocarditis
(C) Pneumonia
(D) Rheumatic fever
(E) Systemic lupus erythematosus

question:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, and difficulty walking up stairs. He had been well until 1 week ago, when he developed rhinorrhea, cough, and a sore throat. These symptoms resolved spontaneously 2 days ago. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. On arrival, he is pale and in moderate respiratory distress. Pulse is 120/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. On pulmonary examination, crackles are heard throughout the lung fields. On cardiac examination, a gallop is heard. S1 is soft. A grade 2/6, high-pitched holosystolic murmur is heard best at the apex. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Why are the other choices not likely the answer?
(A) Glomerulonephritis
(B) Myocarditis
(C) Pneumonia
(D) Rheumatic fever
(E) Systemic lupus erythematosus

metadata.medical_code_description: Inflammation of the myocardium due to a viral infection, often occurring after a recent upper respiratory viral prodrome and presenting with acute heart failure and/or cardiogenic shock (eg, tachycardia, hypotension, gallop rhythm, pulmonary edema, and functional mitral regurgitation).

llm_extracted_info.condition_text: No other abnormalities are noted on physical examination.

llm_final_answer.justification: The combination of a recent viral prodrome (item 3, weight 5), acute heart‑failure signs (items 2, 6, 7, 9, weight 4‑7), and cardiogenic shock (item 4, weight 8) strongly points to myocarditis. Other options lack supporting findings: glomerulonephritis would present with renal signs; pneumonia would have fever and focal lung findings without a gallop or murmur; rheumatic fever usually follows a longer latency and includes migratory arthritis; systemic lupus erythematosus would have multisystem manifestations not present here.

question:
Five days after admission to the hospital for management of an ST-elevation myocardial infarction, a 59-year-old
man has the sudden onset of severe abdominal and bilateral lower extremity pain, cyanosis of the lower body, and
paresthesias. On hospital days 1 and 2, he received vasopressor and inotropic therapy. On hospital day 2,
echocardiography showed extensive anterolateral akinesis of the left ventricle. He has no history of serious illness.
His medications are metoprolol, lisinopril, simvastatin, and dalteparin. He appears to be in acute distress. Pulse is
105/min and regular, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Examination shows lower body
cyanosis to the level of the costal margins. Crackles are heard over the lower lung fields bilaterally. Distant heart
sounds but no murmurs are heard. The abdomen is nondistended and nontender. Pulses are 1+ in the upper
extremities and absent in the lower extremities. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the lower extremities. Sensation to touch
and temperature is decreased over the lower extremities. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is
the most likely explanation for this patient’s clinical findings?

(A) Aortic dissection
(B) Aortic embolism
(C) Pericardial tamponade
(D) Right ventricular failure
(E) Ventricular rupture

the most likely explanation for this patient’s clinical findings?

(C) Pericardial tamponade
(D) Right ventricular failure
(E) Ventricular rupture

metadata.medical_code_name: Embolism and thrombosis of abdominal aorta
metadata.medical_code_description: Acute occlusion of the abdominal aorta due to embolus or thrombus (e.g., saddle embolus), typically causing sudden severe pain, lower-body ischemia/cyanosis, absent lower-extremity pulses, neurologic deficits, and hemodynamic collapse.

llm_final_answer.justification: The combination of sudden bilateral lower‑extremity pain, cyanosis, absent lower pulses (item 12, weight 10), and a recent extensive LV wall‑motion abnormality that predisposes to thrombus formation (item 4, weight 7) strongly points to an embolus from the left ventricle lodging in the abdominal aorta, producing acute lower‑body ischemia. Lesser‑weight findings (hypotension, distant heart sounds) are secondary to the resulting shock but do not explain the selective loss of lower‑extremity perfusion, making aortic embolism the most likely explanation.

metadata.medical_code_name: Embolism and thrombosis of abdominal aorta
metadata.medical_code_description: Acute occlusion of the abdominal aorta due to embolus or in-situ thrombosis, causing sudden severe ischemia of the lower body (eg, abrupt bilateral leg pain, paresthesias/weakness, cyanosis, and absent lower-extremity pulses). In this clinical context (large anterior STEMI with left-ventricular akinesis), the most likely source is an LV mural thrombus with systemic arterial embolization to the distal/abdominal aorta (aortoiliac occlusion/saddle embolus physiology).

llm_final_answer.justification: The most influential facts are the sudden severe abdominal and bilateral lower‑extremity pain with cyanosis and absent lower pulses (items 2 and 8, weight 10), and the recent extensive LV akinesis (item 4, weight 9) which creates a source for a mural thrombus that can embolize to the abdominal aorta, producing acute lower‑body ischemia. The isolated lower‑body findings with preserved upper‑body pulses (item 7) argue against aortic dissection, tamponade, RV failure, or ventricular rupture, making aortic embolism the most likely explanation.

answerable: I'm a 59‑year‑old man admitted for an ST‑elevation myocardial infarction, and the exam says I have pulses in my upper extremities but none in my lower extremities, lower‑body cyanosis to the level of the costal margins, crackles over lower lung fields bilaterally, distant heart sounds with no murmurs, and a nondistended, nontender abdomen—what does this mean?

I have muscle strength 3/5 in my lower extremities and reduced sensation to touch and temperature there, my lower body is cyanotic up to the costal margins, I have crackles over the lower lung fields bilaterally, distant heart sounds with no murmurs, and my abdomen is nondistended and nontender; five days after admission I suddenly developed severe abdominal and bilateral lower‑extremity pain, cyanosis of the lower body, and paresthesias, and on hospital‑day 2 an echocardiogram showed extensive anterolateral akinesis of the left ventricle.

Five days after I was admitted I suddenly got severe stomach and both leg pain, my lower body turned blue, I felt tingling, my heart rate is 105 regular, I’m breathing 24 times a minute, my blood pressure is 80 over 60, I feel a weak pulse in my arms and no pulse in my legs.

Five days after I was admitted I suddenly got severe abdominal and both leg pain, my lower body turned cyanotic, and I felt paresthesias; on hospital day 2 the echo showed extensive anterolateral akinesis of the left ventricle, and now my leg muscle strength is 3/5 with decreased sensation to touch and temperature in the lower extremities.
hard_but_fair: My lower body was cyanotic up to the costal margins, I had crackles over both lower lung fields, distant heart sounds without murmurs, and my abdomen was nondistended and nontender; on hospital days 1‑2 I received vasopressor and inotropic therapy.

question:
A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She received the diagnosis of
 hypertension 3 weeks ago, and lisinopril therapy was begun at that time. She has had a constant, nonproductive,
 hacking cough for 2 weeks but has not had any other problems. She has no history of serious illness and takes no
 other medications. She does not smoke. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily. She does aerobic exercise for
 30 minutes four to five times weekly. Her blood pressure has decreased from 164/92 mm Hg 3 weeks ago to 140/84
 mm Hg today. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in
 management of this patient's cough?

 (A) Pulmonary function tests
 (B) CT scan of the chest
 (C) Course of prednisone
 (D) Discontinuation of lisinopril
 (E) Use of a cough suppressant
 (F) No change in management is indicated at this time

 (E) Use of a cough suppressant

question:
A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She received the diagnosis of
 hypertension 3 weeks ago, and lisinopril therapy was begun at that time. She has had a constant, nonproductive,
 hacking cough for 2 weeks but has not had any other problems. She has no history of serious illness and takes no
 other medications. She does not smoke. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily. She does aerobic exercise for
 30 minutes four to five times weekly. Her blood pressure has decreased from 164/92 mm Hg 3 weeks ago to 140/84
 mm Hg today. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in
 management of this patient's cough and why not the other choices?

 (A) Pulmonary function tests
 (B) CT scan of the chest
 (C) Course of prednisone
 (D) Discontinuation of lisinopril
 (E) Use of a cough suppressant
 (F) No change in management is indicated at this time

metadata.medical_code_name: Adverse effect of angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, initial encounter
metadata.medical_code_description: This code captures an adverse effect due to therapeutic use of an ACE inhibitor (eg, lisinopril). A classic adverse effect is a persistent, nonproductive cough caused by increased bradykinin; the patient is presenting for initial evaluation/management of this medication-related adverse effect.

question:
A 43-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination 1 week after she was discharged from the hospital following an overnight admission for an episode of crushing, aching chest pain. The pain was located behind her sternum and radiated to her left jaw and shoulder. She also had shortness of breath, palpitations, and nausea. Initial ECG obtained on admission showed ST-segment depressions in leads V₃ through V₆. Nitroglycerin was administered, and the chest pain resolved. Follow-up serial ECGs disclosed no abnormalities and serum troponin concentrations were within the reference ranges. Cardiac catheterization obtained the next morning showed no substantial narrowing of the coronary arteries. At discharge, the patient declined medication to prevent recurrence of pain. The patient reports that since discharge, she has had two episodes of chest discomfort lasting 2 to 4 minutes, similar in location and quality to the pain precipitating her hospitalization. Medical history otherwise is unremarkable and she takes no routine medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prescribe at this time?

 (A) Diltiazem
 (B) Lisinopril
 (C) Propranolol
 (D) Warfarin
 (E) No pharmacotherapy is indicated at this time

llm_final_answer.justification: The most influential facts are the normal coronary angiogram (item 5, weight 8) indicating coronary vasospasm, the initial ST‑segment depressions (item 3, weight 6) and recurrent brief chest pain episodes (item 7, weight 6). question:
A 43-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination 1 week after she was discharged from the hospital following an overnight admission for an episode of crushing, aching chest pain. The pain was located behind her sternum and radiated to her left jaw and shoulder. She also had shortness of breath, palpitations, and nausea. Initial ECG obtained on admission showed ST-segment depressions in leads V₃ through V₆. Nitroglycerin was administered, and the chest pain resolved. Follow-up serial ECGs disclosed no abnormalities and serum troponin concentrations were within the reference ranges. Cardiac catheterization obtained the next morning showed no substantial narrowing of the coronary arteries. At discharge, the patient declined medication to prevent recurrence of pain. The patient reports that since discharge, she has had two episodes of chest discomfort lasting 2 to 4 minutes, similar in location and quality to the pain precipitating her hospitalization. Medical history otherwise is unremarkable and she takes no routine medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prescribe at this time? Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prescribe at this time and why not the other choices?

 (A) Diltiazem
 (B) Lisinopril
 (C) Propranolol
 (D) Warfarin
 (E) No pharmacotherapy is indicated at this time

Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prescribe at this time and why not the other choices?

 (B) Lisinopril
 (C) Propranolol
 (D) Warfarin
 (E) No pharmacotherapy is indicated at this time

llm_final_answer.justification: The combination of normal coronary angiography (item 5, weight 8) with ischemic ECG changes (item 3, weight 6) and brief recurrent chest pain episodes (item 6, weight 6) is most consistent with coronary vasospasm (variant angina). Calcium‑channel blockers such as diltiazem are first‑line therapy for this condition, whereas beta‑blockers (C) can exacerbate spasm, ACE inhibitors (B) have no benefit, anticoagulation (D) is unnecessary, and no therapy (E) would leave the vasospasm untreated. Hence, option A is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

question:
A 50-year-old man returns to the office for a follow-up examination. During the past 2 months, he has had increased blood pressure readings during several checks at the office and at home. He says he has felt well. He has major depressive disorder and gout. Medications are fluoxetine and allopurinol. His maternal grandfather had congestive heart failure and the patient's older brother has hypertension. The patient has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 32 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m². Pulse is 70/min and blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg. Physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in this patient?
(A) Amlodipine
(B) Doxazosin
(C) Hydrochlorothiazide
(D) Lisinopril
(E) Metoprolol
question_context: A 50-year-old man returns to the office for a follow-up examination. The patient has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 32 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m². Pulse is 70/min and blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg. Physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in this patient?
options:
(A) Amlodipine
(B) Doxazosin
(C) Hydrochlorothiazide
(D) Lisinopril
(E) Metoprolol

llm_final_answer.justification: The patient has gout (item 4) and is already on allopurinol (item 5); thiazide diuretics such as hydrochlorothiazide can raise serum uric acid and precipitate gout flares, making them contraindicated in this context. The hypertension (item 2) requires treatment, but the gout history makes hydrochlorothiazide the unsuitable choice.

question:
A healthy 30-year-old woman participates in a study of the relationship between cardiovascular function and posture. Placed in a room with a comfortable temperature (72°F) and humidity (40%), she moves from a standing to a supine position. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely in the reflex control of this woman's cardiovascular
system?

(A) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity, Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity, and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart increase
(B) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity and Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity increase, while Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart decrease
(C) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart increase, while Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity decrease
(D) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity increase, while Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart decrease
(E) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity decrease, while Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart increase
(F) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart  decrease, while Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity increase
(G) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity and Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity decrease, while Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart increase
(H) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity, Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity, and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart decrease
correct_response: (A) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity, Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity, and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart increase

answerable: When I go from standing to supine, my elevated baroreceptor firing causes increased vagal efferent activity to my heart, reduced sympathetic outflow, and it also raises my central blood volume and arterial pressure—what does this mean?

When I change from standing to supine, the rise in arterial pressure stimulates my carotid sinus baroreceptors, increasing their firing activity, which leads to increased vagal efferent (parasympathetic) activity to the heart and reduced sympathetic outflow, and it also increases central blood volume.

When I go from standing to lying down, my arterial pressure rises, which stimulates the carotid sinus baroreceptors and increases their firing activity, and my central blood volume also goes up—why does this happen?

When I lie down flat, my arterial pressure goes up, which stimulates the carotid sinus baroreceptors and makes them fire more. Lying supine also pushes more blood back to my heart, stretching the atria and raising the activity of the atrial stretch receptors. So moving to a supine position increases my central blood volume and arterial pressure.
hard_but_fair: I change from standing to lying down, and it makes my central blood volume and arterial pressure go up—why does that happen?
When I transition to lying on my back (supine), my central blood volume and arterial pressure increase.
boundary_tests: When I'm lying down, my increased venous return stretches my atria and raises atrial stretch receptor activity, and the elevated baroreceptor firing increases vagal efferent activity to my heart while reducing sympathetic outflow—what's happening?
When I go from standing to lying down, my central blood volume and arterial pressure increase.

question:
A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 12-hour history of chest pain. Physical examination shows
no abnormalities. Serum studies show an increased troponin I concentration. The diagnosis of myocardial infarction
is made. It is suspected that this patient's condition deteriorated as a result of ischemia-reperfusion injury. The
increased serum troponin I concentration in this patient most likely occurred as a result of which of the following
processes?

(A) Increased enzyme secretion
(B) Increased enzyme synthesis
(C) Karyolysis
(D) Lysis of the endoplasmic reticulum
(E) Lysis of the plasma membrane
(F) Mitochondrial swelling
question_context:
A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 12-hour history of chest pain. Physical examination shows
no abnormalities. Serum studies show an increased troponin I concentration. The diagnosis of myocardial infarction
is made. It is suspected that this patient's condition deteriorated as a result of ischemia-reperfusion injury. The
increased serum troponin I concentration in this patient most likely occurred as a result of which of the following
processes?
options:
(A) Increased enzyme secretion
(B) Increased enzyme synthesis
(C) Karyolysis
(D) Lysis of the endoplasmic reticulum
(E) Lysis of the plasma membrane
(F) Mitochondrial swelling

question:
A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 12-hour history of chest pain. Physical examination shows
no abnormalities. Serum studies show an increased troponin I concentration. The diagnosis of myocardial infarction
is made. It is suspected that this patient's condition deteriorated as a result of ischemia-reperfusion injury. Which of the following processes caused the patient's serum troponin I concentration increased? Discuss each item. 

(A) Increased enzyme secretion
(B) Increased enzyme synthesis
(C) Karyolysis
(D) Lysis of the endoplasmic reticulum
(E) Lysis of the plasma membrane
(F) Mitochondrial swelling
question_context:
A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 12-hour history of chest pain. Physical examination shows
no abnormalities. Serum studies show an increased troponin I concentration. The diagnosis of myocardial infarction
is made. It is suspected that this patient's condition deteriorated as a result of ischemia-reperfusion injury. Which of the following processes caused the patient's serum troponin I concentration increased? Discuss each item.
options:
(A) Increased enzyme secretion
(B) Increased enzyme synthesis
(C) Karyolysis
(D) Lysis of the endoplasmic reticulum
(E) Lysis of the plasma membrane
(F) Mitochondrial swelling

metadata.medical_code_description: An acute myocardial infarction (heart attack) in which the specific site (e.g., STEMI/NSTEMI location) is not documented. In this clinical scenario, elevated troponin I reflects myocardial cell injury/necrosis with loss of membrane integrity and release of intracellular contractile proteins into the bloodstream, which can be exacerbated by ischemia-reperfusion injury.

llm_final_answer.justification: The increased serum troponin I (item 4, weight 10) indicates release of intracellular cardiac proteins, which occurs when the plasma membrane is disrupted (item 6 supports a reperfusion‑related membrane injury). Thus, lysis of the plasma membrane (option E) best explains the troponin rise.

question:
An investigator is studying heart development in an experimental animal model. The animal model is genetically modified so that no cardiac neural crest cells develop. What cardiac abnormality would be most probably triggered in this model? Why is that your choice among the others?

(A) Atrial septal defect
(B) Coarctation of the aorta
(C) Mitral stenosis
(D) Persistent truncus arteriosus
(E) Transposition of the great arteries
question_context: An investigator is studying heart development in an experimental animal model. The animal model is genetically modified so that no cardiac neural crest cells develop. What cardiac abnormality would be most probably triggered in this model? Why is that your choice among the others?
options:
(A) Atrial septal defect
(B) Coarctation of the aorta
(C) Mitral stenosis
(D) Persistent truncus arteriosus
(E) Transposition of the great arteries

metadata.medical_code_description: A congenital conotruncal cardiac malformation due to failure of neural crest–derived aorticopulmonary (conotruncal) septation, resulting in a single common arterial trunk arising from the heart that supplies the systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations, typically with an associated ventricular septal defect.

llm_extracted_info.condition: The experimental animal model is genetically modified so that no cardiac neural crest cells develop.
llm_extracted_info.explanation: This is the central developmental defect that determines which cardiac anomalies can arise; neural crest cells are critical for outflow tract septation and aortic arch formation.
llm_extracted_info.condition_text: The experimental animal model is genetically modified so that no cardiac neural crest cells develop.
llm_extracted_info.rationale: Specifies genetic alteration, fitting genetics risk factor

llm_final_answer.justification: The absence of cardiac neural crest cells prevents proper formation of the aorticopulmonary septum, leading to a single arterial trunk (persistent truncus arteriosus). This aligns with item 1, the highest‑weighted fact.

answerable.condition: The experimental animal model is genetically modified so that no cardiac neural crest cells develop.
answerable.explanation: This is the central developmental defect that determines which cardiac anomalies can arise; neural crest cells are critical for outflow tract septation and aortic arch formation.
answerable.condition_text: The experimental animal model is genetically modified so that no cardiac neural crest cells develop.
answerable.rationale: Specifies genetic alteration, fitting genetics risk factor

question:
A 12-year-old girl is brought to the office because of a 2-day history of chest pain. She also had a 3-day history of fever that has since resolved. When she lies down, the pain worsens and she has shortness of breath. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). A friction rub is heard. Which of the following is the most likely causal infectious agent?

(A) Coxsackievirus
(B) Mumps virus
(C) Staphylococcus aureus
(D) Staphylococcus epidermidis
(E) Viridans streptococcus
question_context: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the office because of a 2-day history of chest pain. She also had a 3-day history of fever that has since resolved. When she lies down, the pain worsens and she has shortness of breath. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). A friction rub is heard. Which of the following is the most likely causal infectious agent?
options:
(A) Coxsackievirus
(B) Mumps virus
(C) Staphylococcus aureus
(D) Staphylococcus epidermidis
(E) Viridans streptococcus

question:
A 12-year-old girl is brought to the office because of a 2-day history of chest pain. She also had a 3-day history of fever that has since resolved. When she lies down, the pain worsens and she has shortness of breath. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). A friction rub is heard. What is the etiologic agent for this case and explain the pathology?

(A) Coxsackievirus
(B) Mumps virus
(C) Staphylococcus aureus
(D) Staphylococcus epidermidis
(E) Viridans streptococcus
question_context: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the office because of a 2-day history of chest pain. She also had a 3-day history of fever that has since resolved. When she lies down, the pain worsens and she has shortness of breath. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). A friction rub is heard. What is the etiologic agent for this case and explain the pathology?
options:
(A) Coxsackievirus
(B) Mumps virus
(C) Staphylococcus aureus
(D) Staphylococcus epidermidis
(E) Viridans streptococcus

metadata.medical_code_description: Acute inflammation of the pericardial sac due to an infectious etiology (most commonly viral in children/adolescents, classically Coxsackievirus B). Pathology involves acute pericardial inflammation with fibrinous/serofibrinous exudate and pericardial surface irritation, producing a pericardial friction rub and sharp, pleuritic chest pain that worsens when supine (and typically improves when sitting up/leaning forward); may be accompanied by a small pericardial effusion.

llm_final_answer.justification: The presence of a pericardial friction rub (item 6, weight 10) and positional chest pain worsening when supine (item 3, weight 8) indicate acute pericarditis. In a 12‑year‑old (item 1, weight 7) with a recent resolved fever (item 5, weight 6), the most common etiologic agent is Coxsackievirus, a typical cause of viral pericarditis in children.

question:
A 39-year-old woman comes to the office because of gradually increasing shortness of breath while doing her usual
household activities. She also reports fatigue, a feeling of heaviness in her chest with exertion, trouble sleeping, and the very
recent onset of a rapid heart beat and fluttering in her chest. She says, "I was always sick as a child." She does not smoke
cigarettes, and she is not currently taking any medications other than occasional aspirin. Her father died of a myocardial
infarction at age 55 years. She is married and has two teenaged children. She did have some shortness of breath at the end of
her second pregnancy. Physical examination today shows a thin woman with an irregular pulse of 130/min. Thyroid gland is
normal to palpation. There is a prominent diastolic rumble heard best over the apical area of her heart. Lungs are clear; there
is no hepatomegaly or pretibial edema. Which of the following is the most helpful diagnostic study at this time?
(A) Chest x-ray
(B) ECG
(C) Serum anti-streptolysin O titer
(D) Serum C-reactive protein concentration
(E) Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) concentration

her second pregnancy. Physical examination today shows a thin woman with an irregular pulse of 130/min. Thyroid gland is
normal to palpation. There is a prominent diastolic rumble heard best over the apical area of her heart. Lungs are clear; there
is no hepatomegaly or pretibial edema. Which of the following is the most helpful diagnostic study at this time?

(A) Chest x-ray
(B) ECG
(C) Serum anti-streptolysin O titer
(D) Serum C-reactive protein concentration
(E) Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) concentration

question:
A 39-year-old woman comes to the office because of gradually increasing shortness of breath while doing her usual
household activities. She also reports fatigue, a feeling of heaviness in her chest with exertion, trouble sleeping, and the very
recent onset of a rapid heart beat and fluttering in her chest. She says, ""I was always sick as a child."" She does not smoke
cigarettes, and she is not currently taking any medications other than occasional aspirin. Her father died of a myocardial
infarction at age 55 years. She is married and has two teenaged children. She did have some shortness of breath at the end of
her second pregnancy. Physical examination today shows a thin woman with an irregular pulse of 130/min. Thyroid gland is
normal to palpation. There is a prominent diastolic rumble heard best over the apical area of her heart. Lungs are clear; there
is no hepatomegaly or pretibial edema. Which of the following diagnostic studies would be the most helpful at this time? Why not the other choices?
(A) Chest x-ray
(B) ECG
(C) Serum anti-streptolysin O titer
(D) Serum C-reactive protein concentration
(E) Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) concentrationn

llm_final_answer.justification: The irregular tachycardia (item 5, weight 8) and diastolic apical rumble (item 7, weight 9) point to mitral stenosis with new‑onset atrial fibrillation. An ECG (item 2) is the most helpful study to confirm atrial fibrillation and assess atrial enlargement, directly addressing the primary clinical problem, whereas the other options (chest X‑ray, ASO titer, CRP, TSH) would provide less immediate diagnostic value.

question:
A 31-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, who is at 32 weeks' gestation, is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-week history
of progressive dyspnea and wheezing. She says her heart is "racing" and she is coughing up a small amount of blood-streaked
sputum. Medical history is significant for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. An intravenous catheter is
placed. Vital signs are temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse 132/min, respirations 32/min, and blood pressure 135/78 mm Hg.
Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Auscultation of the lungs discloses
decreased breath sounds at the bases with expiratory crackles bilaterally. Cardiac examination discloses an irregularly
irregular rhythm, an indistinct point of maximal impulse, and a loud S1. A grade 3/6, low-pitched, diastolic, rumbling
murmur is audible at the apex; a distinct snapping sound precedes the murmur. Fetal heart rate is 144/min. Which of the
following is the most likely cause of the findings in this patient?
(A) Atrial septal defect with development of pulmonary hypertension
(B) Chronic mitral regurgitation secondary to rheumatic heart disease
(C) Coarctation of the aorta
(D) Congenital aortic stenosis
(E) Mitral stenosis complicated by atrial fibrillation
correct_response: (E) Mitral stenosis complicated by atrial fibrillation

llm_final_answer.answer: (E) Mitral stenosis complicated by atrial fibrillation
llm_final_answer.justification: The presence of a loud S1, an opening snap, and a low‑pitched diastolic rumbling murmur at the apex (item 13, weight 10) is classic for mitral stenosis. This is accompanied by an irregularly irregular rhythm (item 10, weight 9) indicating atrial fibrillation, and the patient’s pregnancy (item 1, weight 8) predisposes to decompensation, explaining the dyspnea, wheezing, hemoptysis (items 2‑3) and pulmonary edema signs (items 6‑9). These high‑weight findings collectively point to mitral stenosis with atrial fibrillation as the most likely cause.

question:
A 31-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, who is at 32 weeks' gestation, is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-week history
of progressive dyspnea and wheezing. She says her heart is "racing" and she is coughing up a small amount of blood-streaked
sputum. Medical history is significant for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. An intravenous catheter is
placed. Vital signs are temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse 132/min, respirations 32/min, and blood pressure 135/78 mm Hg.
Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Auscultation of the lungs discloses
decreased breath sounds at the bases with expiratory crackles bilaterally. Cardiac examination discloses an irregularly
irregular rhythm, an indistinct point of maximal impulse, and a loud S1. A grade 3/6, low-pitched, diastolic, rumbling
murmur is audible at the apex; a distinct snapping sound precedes the murmur. Fetal heart rate is 144/min. Which of these conditions is the most likely diagnosis and explain why the other answers are incorrect?

(A) Atrial septal defect with development of pulmonary hypertension
(B) Chronic mitral regurgitation secondary to rheumatic heart disease
(C) Coarctation of the aorta
(D) Congenital aortic stenosis
(E) Mitral stenosis complicated by atrial fibrillation
correct_response: (E) Mitral stenosis complicated by atrial fibrillation

llm_final_answer.answer: (E) Mitral stenosis complicated by atrial fibrillation
llm_final_answer.justification: The combination of an opening snap (item 6) followed by a low‑pitched diastolic rumbling murmur at the apex (item 5), a loud S1 (item 5), and an irregularly irregular tachyarrhythmia (item 4) strongly points to mitral stenosis with atrial fibrillation. Hemoptysis (item 3) and pulmonary crackles (item 8) are classic complications of severe mitral stenosis. Other options lack these key findings: ASD with pulmonary hypertension would produce a systolic ejection murmur and fixed split S2, not a diastolic rumble; chronic mitral regurgitation yields a holosystolic murmur, not diastolic; coarctation presents with upper‑extremity hypertension; congenital aortic stenosis produces a systolic ejection murmur. Hence, (E) is the most likely diagnosis.

question:
Patient Information
Age: 62 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Ethnicity: white, self-identified
Site of Care: office

History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: "My legs hurt when I walk, and it's getting worse."
History of Present Illness: 3-month history of worsening leg pain, pain exacerbated by walking; peak intensity after 1 block, pain resolves completely with rest, pain rated 4/10 at worst
Past Medical History: hypertension, mild angina, type 2 diabetes mellitus
Medications: lisinopril, metoprolol, furosemide, glyburide, lovastatin
Allergies: no known drug allergies
Psychosocial History: has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 44 years

Physical Examination
Temp 36.0°C (96.8°F) 
Pulse 72/min
Resp 14/min
BP 140/90 mmHg
O2Sat -
Height 164 cm (5 ft 5 in)
Weight 90 kg (198 lb)
BMI 33 kg/m²
 
Appearance: no acute distress
HEENT: funduscopic shows grade 2/4 arteriovenous nicking
Neck: no jugular venous distention
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation; mildly diminished lung sounds
Cardiac: no bruits; distant heart sounds
Abdominal: obese; no tenderness, guarding, masses, bruits, or hepatosplenomegaly
Extremities: no joint erythema, edema, or warmth; no hair on toes; no femoral bruits; dorsalis pedis, radial, and femoral
pulses intact
Neurologic: sensation to vibration intact
Question: Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study?
(A) Ankle brachial index
(B) Arteriography
(C) ECG
(D) Echocardiography
(E) MUGA scan

llm_final_answer.justification: The patient's classic intermittent claudication (item 1, 2) combined with strong atherosclerotic risk factors (item 3) and lack of acute cardiac symptoms (item 9) makes a non‑invasive vascular test the most appropriate next step. The ABI is the recommended initial study for suspected peripheral arterial disease, whereas arteriography (B) is invasive and reserved for treatment planning, ECG (C), echocardiography (D), and MUGA scan (E) address cardiac evaluation, which is not indicated here.

question:
Essepro™ (lesystolol) Reduces Blood Pressure Significantly
No significant interactions with commonly used medications were observed. No significant interactions with hydrochlorthiazide, furosemide, losartan orlisinopril. No significant interactions with digoxin, warfarin or simvastatin. Drugs that inhibit CYP2C9 can increase plasma levels of Essepro. Patients on Essepro who are also treated with drugs that inhibit or induce this enzyme shhould be monitored closely, and dosage of Essepro may need to be adjusted based on blood pressure response.
Important Safety Information
Patients treated with Essepro should be advised against sudden discontinuation of therapy. When discontinuing therapy, dosage should be gradually tapered over 2 weeks. Essepro is contraindicated i patients with bradycardia, heart block greater than first degree, cardiogenic shock, decompensated cardiac failure, severe hepatic impairment, and in patients who are hypersensitive to any component of this product. Essepro should be used with caution in patients with peripheral vascular disease, renal impairment or thyrotoxicoses. Caution should be used in diabetics, as beta blockers may mask some manifestations of hypoglycemia. In general, patients with bronchospastic disease should not receive beta blockers.
A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for blood pressure medication management. Medical history is significant for poorly
controlled hypertension, psoriasis, and psoriatic arthritis previously treated with methotrexate. Additional medical history is
significant for alcohol use disorder and elevated liver function tests. Medications include enalapril, spironolactone, and topical
corticosteroids. Vital signs are normal except for a blood pressure of 160/104 mm Hg. Physical examination discloses thick, scaly
plaques on the scalp, buttocks, and upper and lower extremities. There are several spider angiomata on the chest and abdomen. The
abdomen is distended and a fluid wave is noted. She has 2+ lower extremity edema. The patient says she would like to try a new
drug called Essepro to treat her hypertension because she can get a 3-month supply of the medication for free.
66. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the patient's request for the medication?
(A) Essepro should be prescribed because she can get it for free
(B) Essepro should not be prescribed because it can worsen her psoriasis
(C) Essepro should not be prescribed because it is similar to her other medications
(D) Essepro should not be prescribed because the patient has severe liver disease
(E) Essepro should only be used for hypertensive emergencies
correct_response: (D) Essepro should not be prescribed because the patient has severe liver disease

metadata.medical_code_description: Decompensated chronic liver disease due to alcohol use, characterized by cirrhosis with clinically apparent ascites (eg, abdominal distension, fluid wave), which is relevant because severe hepatic impairment can contraindicate or require avoidance/adjustment of certain antihypertensive agents (including some beta blockers).

llm_final_answer.answer: (D) Essepro should not be prescribed because the patient has severe liver disease
llm_final_answer.justification: The presence of markedly elevated liver function tests (item 5, weight 9) and clinical signs of advanced liver disease—spider angiomata (item 8, weight 5) and ascites (item 9, weight 9)—indicates severe hepatic impairment, which is a contraindication for Essepro. These high‑weight items outweigh the need for additional antihypertensive therapy (item 2) and patient preference (item 11). Therefore, the appropriate response is option D.

question:
Essepro™ (lesystolol) Reduces Blood Pressure Significantly
No significant interactions with commonly used medications were observed. No significant interactions with hydrochlorthiazide, furosemide, losartan orlisinopril. No significant interactions with digoxin, warfarin or simvastatin. Drugs that inhibit CYP2C9 can increase plasma levels of Essepro. Patients on Essepro who are also treated with drugs that inhibit or induce this enzyme shhould be monitored closely, and dosage of Essepro may need to be adjusted based on blood pressure response.
Important Safety Information
Patients treated with Essepro should be advised against sudden discontinuation of therapy. When discontinuing therapy, dosage should be gradually tapered over 2 weeks. Essepro is contraindicated i patients with bradycardia, heart block greater than first degree, cardiogenic shock, decompensated cardiac failure, severe hepatic impairment, and in patients who are hypersensitive to any component of this product. Essepro should be used with caution in patients with peripheral vascular disease, renal impairment or thyrotoxicoses. Caution should be used in diabetics, as beta blockers may mask some manifestations of hypoglycemia. In general, patients with bronchospastic disease should not receive beta blockers.
A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for blood pressure medication management. Medical history is significant for poorly
controlled hypertension, psoriasis, and psoriatic arthritis previously treated with methotrexate. Additional medical history is
significant for alcohol use disorder and elevated liver function tests. Medications include enalapril, spironolactone, and topical
corticosteroids. Vital signs are normal except for a blood pressure of 160/104 mm Hg. Physical examination discloses thick, scaly
plaques on the scalp, buttocks, and upper and lower extremities. There are several spider angiomata on the chest and abdomen. The
abdomen is distended and a fluid wave is noted. She has 2+ lower extremity edema. The patient says she would like to try a new
drug called Essepro to treat her hypertension because she can get a 3-month supply of the medication for free.
Among the options, what will be the best response to the patient's request for the medication? Explain why.
(A) Essepro should be prescribed because she can get it for free
(B) Essepro should not be prescribed because it can worsen her psoriasis
(C) Essepro should not be prescribed because it is similar to her other medications
(D) Essepro should not be prescribed because the patient has severe liver disease
(E) Essepro should only be used for hypertensive emergencies
correct_response: (D) Essepro should not be prescribed because the patient has severe liver disease

metadata.medical_code_name: Alcoholic cirrhosis of liver with ascites
metadata.medical_code_description: Cirrhosis of the liver due to alcohol use, complicated by ascites (decompensated chronic liver disease). This condition is relevant because many medications (including some beta-blockers) may be contraindicated or require dose adjustment in severe hepatic impairment.

question:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-day history of nasal congestion, headache, sore throat, and general
malaise. She has developed a cough during the past 24 hours that is mildly productive of clear sputum. Except for occasional
seasonal allergies, she has no previous history of medical problems. She takes no medications on a regular basis but during
the past 3 days she has been taking an over-the-counter oral cold medication. She follows a strict low-fat vegetarian diet and
she drinks three to four glasses of wine per week. She jogs 3 miles a day when she is not sick. Vital signs today are
temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse 90/min, and blood pressure 140/94 mm Hg. Height is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in); weight is
54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m². On physical examination she appears slightly anxious. Nasal mucosa is erythematous and
swollen, and sinuses are nontender. Posterior pharynx is also erythematous but there are no exudates. Lungs are clear on
auscultation and cardiac examination is normal. Repeat blood pressure measurement at the end of the examination is
142/96 mm Hg in the left arm and 138/94 mm Hg in the right arm. Which of the following factors is causing this patient's high blood pressure? Why not the other choices?
(A) Acute viral illness
(B) Chronic sinusitis
(C) Essential hypertension
(D) Her alcohol intake
(E) Over-the-counter cold medication

question:
A 47-year-old man comes to the office to establish care. He recently moved to the area and has not been evaluated by a
physician for more than 3 years. He reports a 1-year history of bilateral knee pain that worsens after prolonged standing, but
he otherwise has felt well. Medical history is unremarkable and his only medication is acetaminophen as needed for his knee
pain. Family history is significant for hypothyroidism in his mother and myocardial infarction in a paternal uncle at age
55 years. The patient drinks five to six beers weekly and does not smoke cigarettes. BMI is 32 kg/m² . Vital signs are
temperature 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse 78/min, respirations 12/min, and blood pressure 138/89 mm Hg. The patient is not in
distress. Physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Results of fasting serum lipid studies obtained in preparation for
today's visit are shown:

Cholesterol
Total 264 mg/dL
HDL 54 mg/dL
LDL 170 mg/dL
Triglycerides 200 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management regarding the patient's laboratory study results?
(A) Prescribe atorvastatin
(B) Prescribe cholestyramine
(C) Recommend diet and low-impact exercise
(D) Refer the patient to a cardiologist
(E) Repeat fasting laboratory studies in 1 month

question:
A 45-year-old man returns to the office for ongoing treatment of tuberculous pericarditis. Pericardiocentesis 9 weeks ago
showed a serosanguineous effusion; culture of the effusion was positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and therapy with
isoniazid, rifampin, and ethambutol was initiated. During the past 2 weeks, he has had increasing shortness of breath on
minimal exertion, cough, pain in the right upper quadrant, and swelling of the lower extremities. BMI is 26 kg/m² .  Vital signs
today are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 100/min, respirations 22/min, and blood pressure 105/65 mm Hg. Physical
examination discloses 10 cm of jugular venous distention. Lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion. Cardiac
examination discloses distant but normal heart sounds. The liver is tender and is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin.
There is 2+ to 3+ pitting edema from the knees distally. HIV antibody test is negative. ECG shows nonspecific ST-T
changes. Chest x-ray today is unchanged from the x-ray obtained at the time of diagnosis, which showed resolution of apical
and perihilar infiltrates and a normal-sized heart. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Add furosemide therapy and reevaluate in 4 weeks
(B) Add prednisone therapy
(C) Add streptomycin and cycloserine therapy
(D) Order bronchoscopy for brushings and cytology
(E) Order echocardiography
question_context:
A 45-year-old man returns to the office for ongoing treatment of tuberculous pericarditis. Pericardiocentesis 9 weeks ago
showed a serosanguineous effusion; culture of the effusion was positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and therapy with
isoniazid, rifampin, and ethambutol was initiated. During the past 2 weeks, he has had increasing shortness of breath on
minimal exertion, cough, pain in the right upper quadrant, and swelling of the lower extremities. BMI is 26 kg/m² .  Vital signs
today are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 100/min, respirations 22/min, and blood pressure 105/65 mm Hg. Physical
examination discloses 10 cm of jugular venous distention. Lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion. Cardiac
examination discloses distant but normal heart sounds. The liver is tender and is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin.
There is 2+ to 3+ pitting edema from the knees distally. HIV antibody test is negative. ECG shows nonspecific ST-T
changes. Chest x-ray today is unchanged from the x-ray obtained at the time of diagnosis, which showed resolution of apical
and perihilar infiltrates and a normal-sized heart. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options:
(A) Add furosemide therapy and reevaluate in 4 weeks
(B) Add prednisone therapy
(C) Add streptomycin and cycloserine therapy
(D) Order bronchoscopy for brushings and cytology
(E) Order echocardiography

metadata.medical_code_description: A chronic condition in which the pericardium becomes thickened and fibrotic (often after infectious or inflammatory pericarditis, including tuberculosis), restricting diastolic filling and leading to predominantly right-sided heart failure findings such as jugular venous distention, hepatomegaly, ascites, and peripheral edema.

llm_final_answer.justification: The combination of recent TB pericarditis (item 1) with new signs of systemic venous congestion (items 2‑3) raises suspicion for constrictive pericarditis; the most appropriate next step is diagnostic imaging to assess pericardial thickness and hemodynamics, i.e., echocardiography (item 8 highest weight).

I’m a 45‑year‑old man who was diagnosed with tuberculous pericarditis 9 weeks ago. A pericardiocentesis then showed a serosanguineous fluid that tested positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and I’m now taking isoniazid, rifampin and ethambutol. Over the past two weeks I’ve noticed that I get shortness of breath even with very little activity, I cough, I have pain in my right upper‑quadrant, and my lower legs are swelling. My doctor’s ECG showed only nonspecific ST‑T changes. On exam today I have a jugular venous distention about 10 cm, my heart sounds are distant but otherwise normal, my lungs are clear, my liver is tender and can be felt about 3 cm below my right costal margin, and I have 2+‑3+ pitting edema from my knees down.

question:
A 45-year-old man returns to the office for ongoing treatment of tuberculous pericarditis. Pericardiocentesis 9 weeks ago
showed a serosanguineous effusion; culture of the effusion was positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and therapy with
isoniazid, rifampin, and ethambutol was initiated. During the past 2 weeks, he has had increasing shortness of breath on
minimal exertion, cough, pain in the right upper quadrant, and swelling of the lower extremities. BMI is 26 kg/m². Vital signs
today are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 100/min, respirations 22/min, and blood pressure 105/65 mm Hg. Physical
examination discloses 10 cm of jugular venous distention. Lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion. Cardiac
examination discloses distant but normal heart sounds. The liver is tender and is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin.
There is 2+ to 3+ pitting edema from the knees distally. HIV antibody test is negative. ECG shows nonspecific ST-T
changes. Chest x-ray today is unchanged from the x-ray obtained at the time of diagnosis, which showed resolution of apical
and perihilar infiltrates and a normal-sized heart. Which of these options will you do next in managing this case? Explain why the other options are incorrect.
(A) Add furosemide therapy and reevaluate in 4 weeks
(B) Add prednisone therapy
(C) Add streptomycin and cycloserine therapy
(D) Order bronchoscopy for brushings and cytology
(E) Order echocardiography

changes. Chest x-ray today is unchanged from the x-ray obtained at the time of diagnosis, which showed resolution of apical

options:
(A) Add furosemide therapy and reevaluate in 4 weeks
(B) Add prednisone therapy
(C) Add streptomycin and cycloserine therapy
(D) Order bronchoscopy for brushings and cytology
(E) Order echocardiography

metadata.medical_code_description: A chronic condition characterized by fibrotic thickening and/or calcification of the pericardium that restricts diastolic filling, leading to signs of predominantly right-sided heart failure (eg, jugular venous distention, hepatomegaly, peripheral edema), often occurring as a late complication of prior pericarditis (including tuberculous pericarditis).

llm_final_answer.justification: The most influential facts are items 6 (right‑sided heart failure signs with clear lungs and normal heart size) and 2‑3 (history of tuberculous pericarditis treated 9 weeks ago), which together strongly suggest evolving constrictive pericarditis. Echocardiography is the appropriate next test to assess pericardial thickness, ventricular interdependence, and confirm constriction. Other options address diuretics, steroids, additional antibiotics, or bronchoscopy, none of which directly evaluate the suspected constrictive physiology.

question:
A 28-year-old man comes to the office for an annual health maintenance examination. He says he has been generally healthy. Three months ago he began walking three times weekly for at least 30 minutes, and he has eliminated salt from his diet after a blood pressure measurement at a local pharmacy was 160/96 mm Hg. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no medications. Family history is remarkable for hyperlipidemia, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. The patient is 188 cm (6 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 135 kg (298 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m². Vital signs are temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse 102/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 156/98 mm Hg. The abdomen is protuberant with no masses. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Results of fasting laboratory studies are shown:

Serum 
Cholesterol
Total - 202 mg/dL
HDL - 33 mg/dL
LDL - 137 mg/dL
Triglycerides - 158 mg/dL
Glucose - 104 mg/dL

Blood 
Hematocrit - 46%
Hemoglobin - 15.6 g/dL
WBC - 9800/mm³

Pharmacotherapy should be directed toward which of the following?
(A) Aiding with metabolism of glucose
(B) Decreasing pulse rate
(C) Decreasing serum LDL-cholesterol concentration
(D) Lowering blood pressure
(E) Suppressing appetite

question:
A 36-year-old woman is referred to the office for evaluation of a fasting serum total cholesterol concentration of 249 mg/dL. She has a family history of early coronary artery disease (CAD) and her father died suddenly at age 46 years of myocardial infarction. She tells you that she has never had chest pain. She is not currently sexually active and has no children. The patient works as an advertising executive. She claims that her high-stress lifestyle makes it impossible for her to eat regular meals or to follow a special diet, and she usually eats fast food. She exercises two or three times a week for about 20 minutes on a treadmill. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Her only medication is acetaminophen for tension headaches. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 76 kg (167 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m². Vital signs today are normal. Physical examination discloses no abnormalities except for mild obesity. Institution of which of the following is the most essential step in the prevention of CAD in this patient?

(A) Biofeedback-based stress reduction program
(B) More rigorous and consistent exercise program
(C) Smoking cessation program
(D) Strict low-calorie diet
(E) Strict low-fat diet

question_context: A 36-year-old woman is referred to the office for evaluation of a fasting serum total cholesterol concentration of 249 mg/dL. She has a family history of early coronary artery disease (CAD) and her father died suddenly at age 46 years of myocardial infarction. She tells you that she has never had chest pain. She is not currently sexually active and has no children. The patient works as an advertising executive. She claims that her high-stress lifestyle makes it impossible for her to eat regular meals or to follow a special diet, and she usually eats fast food. She exercises two or three times a week for about 20 minutes on a treadmill. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Her only medication is acetaminophen for tension headaches. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 76 kg (167 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m². Vital signs today are normal. Physical examination discloses no abnormalities except for mild obesity. Institution of which of the following is the most essential step in the prevention of CAD in this patient? Explain your rationale on each choice.
options:
(A) Biofeedback-based stress reduction program
(B) More rigorous and consistent exercise program
(C) Smoking cessation program
(D) Strict low-calorie diet
(E) Strict low-fat diet

metadata.medical_code_description: Indicates uncomplicated nicotine dependence due to cigarette smoking. In this clinical context, ongoing cigarette use is a major modifiable risk factor for coronary artery disease (CAD), and smoking cessation is the most essential preventive intervention to reduce future CAD risk.

question:
A 47-year-old man is admitted to the hospital through the emergency department because of the sudden onset of palpitations, left-sided chest pain, light-headedness, and shortness of breath that began while he was watching television 2 hours ago. Medical history is remarkable for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The patient is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m². ECG obtained in the emergency department showed atrial fibrillation with narrow QRS complex. Pulse was 146/min. Physical examination was remarkable for rapid heart rate. The patient was given oxygen via nasal cannula and intravenous metoprolol 5 mg every 5 minutes for a total of 15 mg. His pulse slowed to 90/min. Two hours after admission, he is pain free but his pulse is now 160/min. Blood pressure is 122/78 mm Hg. In order to decrease the patient's pulse, which of the following should be administered intravenously?

(A) Adenosine 
(B) Digoxin 
(C) Enalapril 
(D) Lidocaine 
(E) Metoprolol

metadata.medical_code_description: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation characterized by recurrent episodes of atrial fibrillation that terminate spontaneously (typically within 7 days), often presenting with palpitations and rapid ventricular response requiring rate control (e.g., IV beta-blocker or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker).

llm_final_answer.justification: The patient has atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response (items 4‑5, 8). He previously responded to IV metoprolol (item 7) but the rate has risen again, and his blood pressure remains stable, making further IV β‑blockade the appropriate choice. Other options (adenosine, digoxin, enalapril, lidocaine) are not indicated for rate control in AF.

question:
A 47-year-old man is admitted to the hospital through the emergency department because of the sudden onset of palpitations, left-sided chest pain, light-headedness, and shortness of breath that began while he was watching television 2 hours ago. Medical history is remarkable for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The patient is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m². ECG obtained in the emergency department showed atrial fibrillation with narrow QRS complex. Pulse was 146/min. Physical examination was remarkable for rapid heart rate. The patient was given oxygen via nasal cannula and intravenous metoprolol 5 mg every 5 minutes for a total of 15 mg. His pulse slowed to 90/min. Two hours after admission, he is pain free but his pulse is now 160/min. Blood pressure is 122/78 mm Hg. In order to decrease the patient's pulse, which of the following should be administered intravenously? Explain your rationale on each choice.

(A) Adenosine 
(B) Digoxin 
(C) Enalapril 
(D) Lidocaine 
(E) Metoprolol

(E) Metoprolol

llm_final_answer.justification: The patient has atrial fibrillation with a narrow‑QRS rapid ventricular response (items 4, 9). He previously responded well to IV metoprolol, slowing from 146 to 90 beats/min (items 7‑8) and remains hemodynamically stable (item 10), making additional β‑blockade the most appropriate IV option. Adenosine, lidocaine, enalapril, and digoxin are either ineffective for AF rate control or have slower onset/unsuitable mechanisms.

question:
A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department because he developed chest pain and shortness of breath 1 hour ago, shortly after snorting cocaine for the first time. He rates the chest pain as a 7 on a 10-point scale and notes that the pain is radiating down his left arm. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications or any other illicit drugs. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m². The patient is diaphoretic. Vital signs are temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse 110/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 200/100 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion. Auscultation of the heart discloses an audible S1 and S2. There is no edema, cyanosis, or clubbing of the digits. The patient is fully oriented. He is treated with supplemental oxygen, a 325-mg aspirin tablet, and intravenous nitroglycerin and lorazepam. Despite therapy, he continues to have chest pain and shortness of breath. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no ST-segment or T-wave abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate additional pharmacotherapy to initiate at this time?

(A) Carvedilol 
(B) Furosemide 
(C) Metoprolol 
(D) Phentolamine 
(E) Streptokinase

llm_final_answer.justification: The most influential facts are the recent cocaine use (item 1, weight 8) and severe hypertension (item 3, weight 9) with persistent chest pain despite nitrates and benzodiazepines (items 6‑7, weight 7). I'm a 25-year-old man and I started having chest pain and shortness of breath an hour ago after snorting cocaine for the first time, and even with therapy the pain and shortness of breath are still there—what can I do?

question:
A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department because he developed chest pain and shortness of breath 1 hour ago, shortly after snorting cocaine for the first time. He rates the chest pain as a 7 on a 10-point scale and notes that the pain is radiating down his left arm. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications or any other illicit drugs. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m². The patient is diaphoretic. Vital signs are temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse 110/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 200/100 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion. Auscultation of the heart discloses an audible S1 and S2. There is no edema, cyanosis, or clubbing of the digits. The patient is fully oriented. He is treated with supplemental oxygen, a 325-mg aspirin tablet, and intravenous nitroglycerin and lorazepam. Despite therapy, he continues to have chest pain and shortness of breath. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no ST-segment or T-wave abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate additional pharmacotherapy to initiate at this time? Explain your rationale on each choice.

(A) Carvedilol 
(B) Furosemide 
(C) Metoprolol 
(D) Phentolamine 
(E) Streptokinase

llm_final_answer.justification: The most influential facts are the recent cocaine use (item 2, weight 10) causing severe hypertension (item 5, weight 9) and persistent chest pain despite nitroglycerin (item 8, weight 8) with a normal ECG (item 9, weight 8). Cocaine‑induced chest pain is mediated by catecholamine excess; an alpha‑adrenergic blocker such as phentolamine directly counteracts this vasospasm and hypertension. Beta‑blockers (items 1, 3) are contraindicated because unopposed alpha stimulation can worsen vasospasm, and fibrinolysis (choice E) is unnecessary without evidence of infarction. Therefore, phentolamine is the appropriate additional pharmacotherapy.

answerable: I'm a 25-year-old man in the emergency department, I'm diaphoretic, my temperature is 37.5 °C, my pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 200/100 mm Hg, and I have chest pain that's 7/10 and radiates down my left arm.

I’m still having chest pain and shortness of breath despite therapy, my oxygen saturation is 95% on room air, my pupils are equal and reactive, lungs are clear, heart sounds normal, no swelling, cyanosis or clubbing, I’m fully oriented, and I have no past medical history, meds or drug use—what does this mean?

question:
A 78-year-old man, who underwent coronary angiography with stent placement 8 years ago, comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. The patient reports no new symptoms except for shortness of breath and fatigue during exercise that began 3 months ago when he tried to increase the distance of his daily walk from 1 mile to 3 miles. He has not had orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or chest pain. Additional medical history is significant for hypertension, coronary artery disease, dyslipidemia, and polymyalgia rheumatica. The patient also has a heart murmur that was discovered at an armed forces screening physical examination at age 18 years, but it did not prevent him from serving in the military. Medications are metoprolol, atorvastatin, lisinopril, omeprazole, and a low dose of prednisone every other day. The patient is active and manages a small farm. BMI is 26 kg/m². Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 60/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 124/61 mm Hg. Cardiac examination discloses a normal S1, pronounced S2, and a grade 2/6 late systolic murmur heard at the right upper parasternal border. Pulses are normal in contour. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

(A) Decrease the dose of metoprolol
(B) Increase the dose of prednisone
(C) Obtain serum vitamin D concentration
(D) Order a transthoracic echocardiography

question:
A 78-year-old man, who underwent coronary angiography with stent placement 8 years ago, comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. The patient reports no new symptoms except for shortness of breath and fatigue during exercise that began 3 months ago when he tried to increase the distance of his daily walk from 1 mile to 3 miles. He has not had orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or chest pain. Additional medical history is significant for hypertension, coronary artery disease, dyslipidemia, and polymyalgia rheumatica. The patient also has a heart murmur that was discovered at an armed forces screening physical examination at age 18 years, but it did not prevent him from serving in the military. Medications are metoprolol, atorvastatin, lisinopril, omeprazole, and a low dose of prednisone every other day. The patient is active and manages a small farm. BMI is 26 kg/m². Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 60/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 124/61 mm Hg. Cardiac examination discloses a normal S1, pronounced S2, and a grade 2/6 late systolic murmur heard at the right upper parasternal border. Pulses are normal in contour. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Explain your rationale on each choice.

(A) Decrease the dose of metoprolol
(B) Increase the dose of prednisone
(C) Obtain serum vitamin D concentration
(D) Order a transthoracic echocardiography

(B) Increase the dose of prednisone
(C) Obtain serum vitamin D concentration
(D) Order a transthoracic echocardiography

metadata.medical_code_description: Degenerative (nonrheumatic) narrowing of the aortic valve leading to a systolic ejection murmur and potential exertional symptoms (eg, dyspnea, fatigue, syncope, angina). In this vignette, an older patient with a long-standing murmur and new exertional limitation warrants evaluation for progressive aortic valve stenosis, most appropriately with transthoracic echocardiography to assess valve anatomy and severity.
